reviewText:
Sol Survivor is one of my top favorite tower defence games (defence grid is my 2nd fav), Sol doesn't really have much of a story to it but it makes up for it with it's sheer number of tower types and possible tower combinations which is in the 1000's.

It has a good multiplayer system with modes like co-op survival and head to head wars and has quite a large number of maps to play them on and in a recent update a level creater was released.

If you enjoy tower defence games Sol Survivor is one you definitely need to get!
voteText: 33 of 36 people (92%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
This is a classic tower defense game that copies significant features from Defense Grid: The Awakening.  There are numerous uncanny similarities.  That being said, there are many worse formulas to copy than Defense Grid, and I highly recommend this game as well as an excellent entry in the Tower Defense genre (but play Defense Grid first).  It doesn't do a lot to differentiate itself, but it executes well on the basic Tower Defense tropes... tower building and placement, tower synergies, etc.

The campaign is relatively short, but there are numerous ways to replay the same levels giving it longer legs than it would otherwise have.

It is a solid tower defense game that deserves attention.  That being said, if you're only going to play one Tower Defense game, it should still be Defense Grid.

reviewText:
Sol Survivor

Sol Survivor is a tower defence game in which the goal is to hold off an invading alien horde consisting of organic, cybernetic, armoured and air units hell-bent on sucking the souls of your helpless colonists. Worried? You should be! Don't despair as you have been issued with an extravagant variety of turrets including shotgun, machine gun, laser and rocket to name but a few as well as a range of support towers to enhance the abilities of neighbouring weaponry. If that wasn't enough to keep you busy, you have a choice of special abilities that can be called in from off map such as fire bombs and nuclear missiles to aid you in your struggle.

I have been loving this game after picking it up in the Steam Sale. It's a simple concept but well executed. The graphics are good for the genre so should be more than playable no matter what system you're running. The multi-player co-op function is incredibly fun as it adds a lot of replay value to the maps and missions although it is still highly addictive going it alone. The hordes vary depending on the amount of players as well as the difficulty level. You can choose from the standard difficulties or an endless assault (my current record on that is 35 minutes!). Personally, I would like the option of choosing a specific amount of waves as there is a not a big difference between the easiest mode and the most difficult in terms of numbers of waves. As a side note, the soundtrack is sublime. This game is worth every penny of the £1.99 I paid for it in the sale and still would be worth it even at the full price of £7.99 (at the time of writing).

If you love tower defence games, you'll love Sol Survivor!
voteText: 10 of 11 people (91%) found this review helpful 2 people found this review funny

reviewText: Sol Survivor is an excellent tower defense game that has a lot of replay value.  The ability to customize your loadout, the plethora of towers and weapons available, the freedom to place towers where you want, the various multi-player modes...all of these things serve to keep me coming back for more.  It's definitely worth its $9.99 price tag, though there's a demo available if you still aren't sure.\n\nhttps://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ay01Ct_L7o4

reviewText:
It may not have the razzle-dazzle of more recent tower defense games, but Sol Survivor is a solid entry in what is a crowded genre.

Cadenza Interactive does an excellent job in delivering a graphical style that is both elegant and visually appealing. I never felt like I wasn't able to identify what each turret's function was even in the thick of battle. I especially like that each type of turret damage is color coded, allowing you to easily spot where areas of your defense may be lacking in certain damage types. Piercing turrets are yellow, concussive turrets are orange, support fields are green and electrical damage is blue. It affords an interesting temperature" to a fleshed out defense and makes each level a paint-by-numbers process of constructing creep murder.

The soundtrack is exceptional
date: and I must take a moment to point it out. It's not heartpounding
recommended: thrilling or action-y. You play the role of an ensign
hoursPlayed: rapidly rising through the ranks in a battle for humanity's survival. The music fits that theme. It's immersive
helpfulPercent: and desperate. Kudos to the composer
votesHelpful: because the soundtrack is amazing and fitting in every way.\n\nSome tower defense fans will balk at the lack of "mazing" or "zoning". Each map already has its path laid out a la the original Warcraft tower defense maps. You simply place your turrets along the path and attempt to capitalize on the various types of damage you have available and the various creeps you are facing. As above
votesTotal: each tower can deal a certain type of damage. This damage is more or less effective against the various types of creeps
votesFunny: so planning your resource expenditure is necessary for a successful defense. Where Sol Survivor lacks the strategy of "zoning"
commentsCount: it makes up for it in the addition of support powers. Each field commander brings a variety of support abilities to the table which can either be used to shore up a weakness in your tower selection or to bolster an already solid defense strategy. Your satellite arrays adapt to the support powers you use which allows them to level up over time
column17: power and recharge time. The missions are carefully balanced to allow for this feature
column18: making it necessary to take an active role in combat (rather than simply laying down towers and waiting for enough mass to upgrade or place more).\n\nSol Survivor also features multiplayer co-op
column19: which is mind-blowing. I have yet to see another tower defense game offer up the same
column20: and the fact that it has slipped under the radar is disappointing. You will be hard pressed to find partners (there are rarely any random people hosting an open lobby) but the playerbase is still active and you can find partners on the discussion hub. You can also send me an invite. I'm always willing to play.\n\nAll in all
column21: Sol Survivor is an excellent game. It looks gorgeous

column23: but the gameplay is solid. I highly recommend it."

reviewText:
Sol Survivor is yet another indie Tower Defense game. They really are spitting them out on an assembly line these days.

Sol Survivor is one of the better examples though as it takes great care to provide you with a multitude of different play-styles and tactics as well as decent multi-player component although it's a bit depopulated these days.

The rather long campaign provides you with the option of choosing which commander to play as which in turn changes which turrets and abilities are available to you. Everything from the standard Gun" turret to nuke silos and booster towers is available to you from the tower side and on the abilities you have simple damage abilities
date:
slowing and stunning abilities and even an ability that permanently sacrifices the power you use to cast abilities in exchange for more resources to build towers.

The abilities are a big part of the game and where other Tower Defense games like Defense Grid focus on building the most minimalistic defense possible Sol Survivor is all about intelligent tower placement and well timed ability use making it a very thoughtful and tactical game.

Sol Survivor also comes packaged with some excellent multi-player modes which in my opinion is one of the most important things in a Tower Defense game. Unfortunately there aren't a whole lot of people playing this online anymore so unless you got friends to play with you might have a bit of a hard time finding opponents and coop partners.

Probably the most intelligent Tower Defense game on steam and definitely one of the best."

reviewText: Sol Survivor is a tower defense game with some interesting twists. The general gameplay is fairly standard - aliens walk down a path trying to steal your stuff, place towers to stop them, yadda yadda yadda... What makes this game unique are the various commanders" from which you can select before starting a level. Each commander has their own set of turrets (which are placed once and work autonomously) and special abilities (powers that can be used actively by you during the match). This results in a huge variety of playstyles that are available

reviewText: I didn't know what to expect from this game, but it's actually a solid tower defense.  It's pretty easy to get used to and they did a really good job at making effective tutorials to make sure you understand everything.  The difficulty curve was also well constructed.  It makes sure you know the basic concepts first and then gives you more to learn.  You can also unlock different officers who use different kinds of towers which can change how you play the levels.  If you're a fan of tower defenses, this is a pretty good one.

reviewText:
I love Tower Defense games!
But i couldn't bring myself to love this one.

Even with it's awesome use of different Commanders with a specific mixup of abilities, all set in a sci-fi universe, i never caught on. In a moment of weakness i might say that the game had no soul, but i shan't.

The towers and difficulty seemed strangely balanced. When i upgraded a tower i never felt it was worth it. I never got a sense of the math behind it, and that is important in a TD game. The enemies felt even more lifeless then normal TD enemies.
So even with sci-fi, commanders, lots of towers and abilities and also high replayability, i was ultimately bored with an uninteresting game.

What a shame.

reviewText: One of the most unique takes on tower defense, the single player requires you to actually act on your feet as a commander and crush anything getting past your towers by hand, while the multiplayer is some of the most clever mode design you'll encounter (try balancing laying down/upgrading turrets, picking off anything that gets by, and MOUNTING THE ASSAULT ON OTHER PLAYERS WITH CREEPS all at once). Also, if you're like me and play everything windowed, this has one of the best windowed modes I've ever run across. That's like a +2 on my scale.\n\nIt honestly pisses me off that this game doesn't get as much love as the bog-standard Defense Grid, which, admittedly, ♥♥♥♥♥♥ me off.

reviewText:
One of the best co-op tower defense games out there. Lots of different turrets to use and multiple different maps. You can now even make your own maps with the map editor to extend the game's life spawn. Not to mention the value you get for so low price. The co-op survival mode is where this game shines. Lots of hours burned with different turret combinations on various maps.

Sol Survivor is simply amazing and has probably the best price/enjoyment ratio out of my games. It's simple yet addicting.

I really wish there would be sequel for this game...

reviewText: saying this might sound strange when you see what this looks like. but ti may be the best tower defence on steam. 7.5/10

A decent little indie Tower Defence title, this pretty much focuses on doing everything well rather than trying to break new ground.

The basic campaign has you cast as a military officer on the ground, which sets up the interesting premise of selecting 'Executive Officers' - essentially a fancy way of selecting pre-set lists of turrets and support powers. Each one has a slightly different theme, some of which are orientated towards certain strategies and some towards certain 'flavours' - so one officer emphasises sheer pin-point damage while another emphasises... errr.... fire and heat.

After completing the campaign (or rather, acquiring enough medals to unlock all the EXOs), you get a far better option in that you can choose which powers and towers from the full list, but you'd be surprised how hard it is is to put together an effective selection.

Turrets and powers are interesting. You have your basic lasers, machine guns, missile pods etc etc that you'll likely have seen a million times before, plus a few interesting options like pillboxes (machine gun pods that divide their fire between all enemies in range) and various silos (extremely long range, powerful missile sites). Support powers are mainly satellite strikes which range from the obvious (laser beams, missiles, EMP strikes) to the weird (gas bombs, Fear effects, supply drops). There's even a nice encyclopedia to find out about them all.

The only real issue I have with the game is that it looks a lot deeper than it is. The number of creeps that make up the waves looks amazing and you'd think you need evey bit of your tactical skill to handle the various monsters, cyborgs and robots arriving via ground and air... but in reality, all you have to do is build as many lasers and other air/ground-capable turrets on u-bends as you can and bombard everything you can. You can't alter their path so there's a limit to how much you can actually do on levels, and with the exception of a few levels, they're all basically the same - a few spawn sites, one or two bases for you to defend, and some hilly roads between. It isn't helped by taking place over fairly boring landscapes - you get a desert, lunar, snow and volcanic planets that are functionally identical beyond their colour.

Overall it's worth the sale price I paid. Hardcore TD fans will likely power through it fairly quickly, but its fun while it lasts. It just isn't quite as polished or as deep as stuff like Sanctum 2 and Defence Grid: The Awakening.

This is a classic tower defense game and while it's entertaining there are some better choices. That said, if you've played Orc's must die and finished up Sanctum. You might enjoy this one.

It has several levels where you basically make towers and use abilities from the fleet to help supplement them. It can be a challenge but it's not impossible and there are plenty of achievements to be had. I really wish I could've given the multiplayer a try before writing this but unfortunately the game seems mostly dead as of 2014 in terms of an online following with the internet lobby being completely bare so buy this keeping in mind that it's only going to be a solo experience unless you grab a friend to buy it with you.

All that said, there isn't too much that sets it apart from other tower defense games.  I enjoy it, but don't expect anything revolutionary.
Really really fun tower defense.  Nothing original or new about it, just a good example of how fun this game style can be.
Awesome Game!

Sol Survivor - simply one of the best Tower Defense games out there. Relatively free placeable turrets and a variety of weaponry and upgrades with a good amount of different enemies make Sol Survivor one of the cornerstones of nowadays TDs.

The campaign isn't too hard to play. The different commanders make every single level a recurring challenge, it's fun to try every one of them. No matter if you're more into fire-it-up-gameplay or controlling the whole area with more defensive equipment, every commander has an own strategic plan to offer.

The 3d graphics might appear a little old compared to younger games but is still what I would call bearable.

Another highlight is the incredibly beautiful composed Soundtrack, which consists mostly of electronic space sounds and melodies which remind of late 80s synth pop.

All in all a fantastic game!

reviewText:
A well-rounded tower defense game. Good mix of tower placement vs. direct intervention to help fill in the gaps.

Enemies are varied and have different weaknesses. Towers are varied and have different strategies. They also interact with other towers for more destruction.

Multiplayer works well. I love the Shared Bounty mode so that you aren't permanantly sidelined if you suck. Easy enough to learn, but plenty of depth when you're ready for it. We pull this one out at most LAN parties.

Edit: Just wanted to give a shout out that as of Nov 2015 my wife and I still pull this out now and again to try to push each level to at least one hour. Super fun and well balanced.
Fun Tower-Defense game. Early levels might be easy, but later levels are more fun and interesting.
Tower defence puro e semplice,ottimo titolo.
Very entertaining tower defense game with good controller (game pad) support. Well worth the few bucks.
oui
Tower defense that'll eventually blind you with particle effects all over the shop. It's alright, but doesn't really hold your attention.
First time I've ever played a turret defense game. More than satisfied.

A true thinking man's tower defense game.  Every enemy type is designed to counter a specific defense tactic.  For example, some enemies can regenerate health while not being attacked, making staggered towers difficult.  With a wide range of turret and support options (active support is a crucial component of this game, turrets alone won't do everything), Sol offers several tactical routes to accomplish your goals.
Solid TD +MP
Plaaaaay eeeeeet.
Tower defense at it's finest.

I'm a big fan of Tower Defense type games, and this is most definitely one of the best I have ever played.  You just don't know how good one is going to play out until you give it a try, and this is top-notch compared to all the rest of them I've played.  Good, good stuff.

Awesome Tower Defence game. Too bad you can not speed up but the many towers, pre-set players, ability to make a custom player, air support and hard levels compensade for nog being able to speed it up.\n\nGetting all the badges in this game will be a nice challenge but for sure worth the money!
Once the synth kicks in... MEN ARE BORN!!!

Sol Survivor isnt the best tower defence game Ive played, but its still fairly enjoyable. I can recommend it to any fan of the genre who is looking for a different option. The campaign lasts around 10 hours, and when you add survival mode and multiplayer the value for money is good. Turret placement isnt locked to a specific grid, which allows more freedom, but in the heat of battle can also be a bit fiddly. The player can also use support powers to attack enemies or buff towers. There are 26 towers and 19 powers which in theory allows for a wide range of tactics. However the campaign is limited to using prebuilt sets containing 8 of each, and building a custom set of your favourites is only possible in survival. Both modes lack of information about which types of enemies are coming next. Campaign does at least indicate when flying or cloaked enemies are coming, but survival does not. The music is fantastic, but tower sound effects feel flat and the story is also very basic.

Probably one of my favorite indie game tower defenses. The games tower list and upgrades, along with its nice selection of game modes, including a good single player campaign, makes this a favorite among tower defenses for me. A good buy, but you might want to consider a 4 pack purchase, because like me, you'll probably want to play this with your friends.

The challenge of this game comes from the specialists" that give you different abilities and towers to work with...so while the maps might be kind of basic you can make it harde by picking a person that doesn't have your favorite tower."
Great indie tower defense game.  Coop play / survival mode.  Great price
Fun, well-crafted tower defense game that's certainly worth the budget price point.
Tower D game

at first glance, it is a very standard tower defense game, but the huge amount of choice you get with towers and abilities sets it apart from other games of this genre.\n\nif you enjoy tower defense games, you will probably have a lot of fun with this game. i suggest playing on hard difficulty on your first playthrough as tower defense games are a lot less fun when you just breeze through them.
Co-op tower defence.\nDifferent characters to play as, each with its own tower combinations.\nPretty fun.
One of the best, unadulturated traditional tower defense games I've ever played.

Interesting. A little like defense grid, as far as tower variety, but with a different tone. You get a commander for each mission that determines exactly which towers are available on that mission, and that really has a huge impact on the game's strategy. Fun, but I personally prefer Defense Grid. Thanks to Xhadowlord for gifting me this game.

One of the best standard tower defense games I've played.  Feels well balanced.  The dynamic of the support abilities is a lot of fun.  The variety of combinations of towers and support abilities supports whatever playstyle you want to use.\n\nNo mazing though, for people who like that.
Classic Tower Defense at its finest.
saying this might sound strange when you see what this looks like. but ti may be the best tower defence on steam. 7.5/10

A decent little indie Tower Defence title, this pretty much focuses on doing everything well rather than trying to break new ground.

The basic campaign has you cast as a military officer on the ground, which sets up the interesting premise of selecting 'Executive Officers' - essentially a fancy way of selecting pre-set lists of turrets and support powers. Each one has a slightly different theme, some of which are orientated towards certain strategies and some towards certain 'flavours' - so one officer emphasises sheer pin-point damage while another emphasises... errr.... fire and heat.

After completing the campaign (or rather, acquiring enough medals to unlock all the EXOs), you get a far better option in that you can choose which powers and towers from the full list, but you'd be surprised how hard it is is to put together an effective selection.

Turrets and powers are interesting. You have your basic lasers, machine guns, missile pods etc etc that you'll likely have seen a million times before, plus a few interesting options like pillboxes (machine gun pods that divide their fire between all enemies in range) and various silos (extremely long range, powerful missile sites). Support powers are mainly satellite strikes which range from the obvious (laser beams, missiles, EMP strikes) to the weird (gas bombs, Fear effects, supply drops). There's even a nice encyclopedia to find out about them all.

The only real issue I have with the game is that it looks a lot deeper than it is. The number of creeps that make up the waves looks amazing and you'd think you need evey bit of your tactical skill to handle the various monsters, cyborgs and robots arriving via ground and air... but in reality, all you have to do is build as many lasers and other air/ground-capable turrets on u-bends as you can and bombard everything you can. You can't alter their path so there's a limit to how much you can actually do on levels, and with the exception of a few levels, they're all basically the same - a few spawn sites, one or two bases for you to defend, and some hilly roads between. It isn't helped by taking place over fairly boring landscapes - you get a desert, lunar, snow and volcanic planets that are functionally identical beyond their colour.

Overall it's worth the sale price I paid. Hardcore TD fans will likely power through it fairly quickly, but its fun while it lasts. It just isn't quite as polished or as deep as stuff like Sanctum 2 and Defence Grid: The Awakening.

This is a classic tower defense game and while it's entertaining there are some better choices. That said, if you've played Orc's must die and finished up Sanctum. You might enjoy this one.

It has several levels where you basically make towers and use abilities from the fleet to help supplement them. It can be a challenge but it's not impossible and there are plenty of achievements to be had. I really wish I could've given the multiplayer a try before writing this but unfortunately the game seems mostly dead as of 2014 in terms of an online following with the internet lobby being completely bare so buy this keeping in mind that it's only going to be a solo experience unless you grab a friend to buy it with you.

All that said, there isn't too much that sets it apart from other tower defense games.  I enjoy it, but don't expect anything revolutionary.
Really really fun tower defense.  Nothing original or new about it, just a good example of how fun this game style can be.
Awesome Game!

Sol Survivor is a peaceful and fun tower defense game that I've enjoyed the last few years playing co-op survival with friends. Yes, I know it's a tower defense game but I find it oddly relaxing with the music and increasing pace of creep waves.

this game is simply amazing if your into tower defence/strategy games.

Laser, the tower that lets you cash in Energy for money works too well in some missions) while others not so much. Similar with the Actions" available.\n\nThe different "commanders" were the biggest let down
date: I was hoping for something along the lines of the classic Warcraft 3 "Burbenog Tower Defense" which requires co-operative play between completely distinct sets of towers.\n\nThere's a lot to enjoy
recommended: and the multiplayer available here makes this game definitely worth a look."

reviewText: A Very innovative Indy Turret Defence game. Multiplayer, survival, leaderboards.... awesomesauce.

A good addition to the tower defence genre, the inclusion of different commanders" each with a different set of towers means there are different style of completing each level.\n\nRecommended for any tower defence fan"

This games single player campaign is very boring, even for a tower defense game. The game only truely shines in multiplayer, and in that aspect, it is amazing. The amount of customization in game modes, to turrets, to how money is distributed, this game can keep a goup entertained for a long time. And the addition of Survival mode was a good one, as it creates a neverending drive to do better. Take one friend, or take 3, it doesn't matter. The game will adjust to the amount of commanders there are so your game is always balanced for every situation. Good buy if you have friends, if you don't, go make some friends then buy a 4 pack.

Sol Survivor is a really fun Tower Defense game. No build limit for towers of anything like that. You have towers and  support powers to deal with the enemy minions. This game has multiple game modes, but the funniest of them all is survival, endless survival. I recommend this game for fans of the TD genre. This game is funnier with friends than solo. 8/10

Do not get this game! If you obligations, or an addictive personality. Seriously. I don't even like tower defense games, but this one... is so well balanced, each map requires a different strategy of placement and selection of towers and abilities. Fast paced, fun, addictive.... do it.

This is an okay tower defense game, the difficulity settings can be varied from beginner to expert. it gets a bit repetative as the different maps do not feel varried enough.

Sol Survivor - simply one of the best Tower Defense games out there. Relatively free placeable turrets and a variety of weaponry and upgrades with a good amount of different enemies make Sol Survivor one of the cornerstones of nowadays TDs.

The campaign isn't too hard to play. The different commanders make every single level a recurring challenge, it's fun to try every one of them. No matter if you're more into fire-it-up-gameplay or controlling the whole area with more defensive equipment, every commander has an own strategic plan to offer.

The 3d graphics might appear a little old compared to younger games but is still what I would call bearable.

Another highlight is the incredibly beautiful composed Soundtrack, which consists mostly of electronic space sounds and melodies which remind of late 80s synth pop.

All in all a fantastic game!

It's a 5-year-old game now, so is it hugely innovative? Nah. Is it fun? Yes! Grab a 4-pack when it goes on sale and have a blast gunning down aliens with (or against) your friends.\n\nAlso, I really like the music. I can't think of another tower defense game with music that I even noticed.

reviewText:
Sol Survivor, a very underrated or unknown game by most. Not much to it, honestly what you see is what you get, a tower defense game with a basic economy and powers that allows you to destroy hordes of invading aliens to save your people.

A rather lengthy single player campaign is present but the true strength of this game lies in the coop survival feature. I have personally logged over 50 hours playing with friends and it never gets old. A wide variety of towers are availiable ranging from combat to support accompanied with a large selection of abilities" used to help turn the tide of battle.

If you enjoy tower defense games
date: you owe it to yourself to give this one a shot."

reviewText:
I am a fan of tower defence games and i enjoy what Sol Survivor brings to the table. The terrain is three dimensional and organic looking (a bit unusual for this genre), and i like the sense of scale in this game.
So why do i not recommend it? The game doesn't work. For the last couple of years I, and many others, are unable to launch the game for some unknown reason. If you look at the forum discussions around this game you can see some people manage to get it running, and others not. I suspect that this will unfortunately not be fixed since it seems that the developer has dropped support for this game.

I did like this game and would play it some more if it worked.

reviewText: Yet another tower defence game, which automatically slants me in favour of despising it, but at the very least it is a very technically competent tower defence game with interesting graphics and three dimensional environments, which at least props it above standard two-dimensional tower defence games or tower assault games.\n\nThe sound is particularly lacklustre and the gameplay, like any typical TD game, is basically a matter of plopping down turrets as soon as you have enough funds to get them. The entire scenario of monsters land here and walk along a path lined with guns shooting at them" is of course extraordinarily contrived
recommended: their attempt to step outside of the bounds of boring single-pathway tower defence gameplay was realised when they introduced orbital strikes. Fort Condor this is not
hoursPlayed: but it's still quite good... for a tower defence game."

reviewText: Tons of fun, for any tower defense lover, and newcomers as well. Love playing co-op too.

If you like Tower Defense games, you should give this one a go.  There are a lot of towers to use, and quite a few Support abilities to use.  From attacking enemies with missles from the sky, to powering up your turrents with increased fire speeds.  While there are a lot of Officers with varying turret setups and powers to use, you can also make a custom Officer, and choose which turrets you want to use.  And you can play co-op with friends, or even in a competetive VS mode, which proves to be quite interesting.

friendと一緒にやれば、これほど楽しいタワーディフェンスは無いだろう

This was pretty fun, all in all the campaign ran me about 7 hours of game play with tons of replay-ability on different difficulty settings and multiplayer coop to boot. All in all, definitely worth the money I spent, will buy more from this developer in the future. 8/10

This is a great take on tower defense, nice graphics, lots of varied weapons and powers, you can play the game buy yourself, online, with 3 friends through the campaign or with 3-7 friends in istant matches, very nice game all round!

Absolutely amazing game if you into tower defense, pretty fantastic if yout not.

Nearly 100 hrs in and i'm still finding new ways to play and new combos and stratagies try.

Even considering the age and graphical simplicity of the game it is still visiually enthralling with every shot and attack being visible allowing you to see the effects of each and every turret.  The effects and variety allow for a visually stunning battle across a vareity of fun and interesting maps wach with its own quirks advantages and dis advantages.  each turret and its attack is visually dicernable from the rest for very colourful and entertaining combination.

Game play is simple but with depth each turret has its own advantages and disadvantages.  While there are definitaly beter turrets within the game each does seem to have its own place with in a build allowing for a wide choice in play styles and tactics.
Additonally the support options -attacks (such as the orbital laser) and buffs (such as speed and crit chance) etc that allow the player to directly efefct the battle field- add an interesting dynamic allowing players to deal with leaks or weaknesses in thier defence line immediately and reliably while giving them somethign to do while they save mass for that all important t3 upgrade or AoE booster turret

A huge menagerie of enemys'(called Creeps) mean you are constantly on the look out for new problems to deal with and ensuring that you have the tools to deal with them and after a few games you will begin to develope a particular dislike for certain creeps and the dreaded boss waves.

As for actually playing? get the 4 pack, get three friends with an evening free and get ready for a game that sucks up more time than minecraft with PvE, CooP and PvP all being available for hours of fun.

And remember, Its not time wasted if its time you enjoyed wasting. :D

I'll give a cautious recommendation for this title.  The variety of powers (and ability to create a custom set), the variety of play modes (including different co-op variants), and the nice soundtrack are definitely strengths.  However, my co-op partner and I seemed to be pushed towards a rather simplistic strategy in order to ensure success.  As opposed to creating various combinations of towers to be placed throughout the map, we typically made one area of about 9 towers, bunched together, referred to online as a kill box."  This strategy proved enormously successful
date: but led to each map playing about the same.  Locate the area (rarely areas) by which all "creeps" would pass on the way to the goal
recommended: and then put down the "kill box." The rest of the map was just watching enemies get obliterated and waiting until we had accumulated enough resources for an upgrade.  It's a nice little title and I don't regret playing it
hoursPlayed: but I do wish it would have demanded a little more creatively from its players."
